channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: National Pride Swells the Crowds for a Polish Saint
item.description: St. Peter’s Square was awash with Polish flags as pilgrims celebrated the canonization ceremony of John Paul II, the first Polish pope.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Afghan Voters Signaling a Turn
item.description: In preliminary results released Saturday, Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai’s and an ardent supporter of the United States, won 45 percent of the votes in the presidential election, but not enough to avoid a runoff.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, shown at his residence in Kabul on Thursday, is one of two candidates expected to compete in a runoff election.

item.title: One of 8 Observers Is Freed by Pro-Russian Forces in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The self-appointed mayor of Slovyansk in eastern Ukraine presented the men at a news conference Sunday, calling them “prisoners of the situation,” before releasing one member for health reasons.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a group of European military observers who were detained on Friday were escorted by antigovernment militants on Sunday to a news conference in Slovyansk, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Syria Misses a Deadline on Chemical Weapons
item.description: Although Syria has made “significant progress,” it missed a second deadline, April 27, for the destruction of its arsenal of chemical weapons, international monitors said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: U.S. and Philippines Agree to a 10-Year Pact on the Use of Military Bases
item.description: The accord will give American warships, planes and troops greater access to bases in the Philippines, returning the United States to a visible presence there for the first time since 1992.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas Shifts on Holocaust
item.description: The president of the Palestinian Authority issued a formal statement calling the Holocaust “the most heinous crime to have occurred against humanity in the modern era.”
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A planned statement by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority grew out of a meeting with a rabbi.

item.title: On Historic Day, John XXIII and John Paul II Become Saints
item.description: Before large, joyous crowds in Rome, Pope Francis performed a joint canonization on Sunday for his papal predecessors, whom he portrayed as “men of courage” with a shared place in history.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Listening Post: In Malaysia, Obama Works to Salve Troubled Ties
item.description: President Obama’s visit to Malaysia underscored the change in the country’s attitude toward the United States, from deep suspicion to a desire for cooperation.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama answered questions from youth leaders in front of a Malaysian flag at the University of Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Sunday.

item.title: News Analysis: For Russia, Negatives Seem to Outweigh Positives of an Invasion
item.description: The reasons for Vladimir V. Putin to refrain from further military adventurism make a long, tangled list.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government troops outside Slovyansk on Saturday. The army is weak, but Ukraine has a history of partisans’ attacking invaders.

item.title: South Korean Leader Accepts Resignation of Premier Over Ferry Disaster
item.description: President Park Geun-hye accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Chung Hong-won but asked him to stay in his post until the government completed its rescue operations, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Chung Hong-won of South Korea announced his resignation at a news conference in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Sanctions Revive Search for Secret Putin Fortune
item.description: President Obama’s response to the Ukraine crisis, while derided by critics as slow and weak, has reinvigorated a 15-year global hunt for the Russian leader’s hidden wealth.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mikhail Klimentiev/Ria Novosti/Kremlin
item.media:description: The Treasury Department says President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has investments in Gunvor, a commodities trading firm.

item.title: South Korean Prime Minister Offers to Resign Over Deadly Ferry Disaster
item.description: Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No. 2 official in the South Korean government, offered “an apology to the people.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean Prime Minister Chung Hong-won announced his resignation at a news conference in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Slovenia Government Shaky After Premier Loses Key Vote
item.description: Prime Minister Alenka Bratusek lost her post as her party’s leader and said that she could not continue in office as a result.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Scots Ponder: Should They Stay or Should They Go?
item.description: Over the last six months the momentum has shifted toward independence, but some fear the fervor that it is creating on either side of the campaign.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Along the Royal Mile in Edinburgh, shopkeepers show their preferences in the September vote for independence with signs and stickers.

item.title: Afghan Panel Claims to Find Secret Prisons
item.description: The commission appointed by President Hamid Karzai said it discovered unlawful prisons run by American and British forces.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Brazilian Ex-Soldier Who Admitted Torture Is Killed
item.description: A former army colonel who admitted that he tortured and killed political prisoners during Brazil’s 1964-1985 military dictatorship was killed in his home outside Rio de Janeiro, the police told local news media on Saturday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Militants Resist Calls to Free European Military Observers Held in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: At least seven officers from Germany, Poland, Sweden, the Czech Republic and Denmark were said to have been detained at a checkpoint outside of Slovyansk. The rebels suggested that they would consider a prisoner exchange.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER

item.title: Hans Hollein, Architect of Witty Designs, Dies at 80
item.description: Mr. Hollein, a Pritzker Prize winner, used not just line but unusual surfaces to make his artistic points.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Quick History: Obama’s High-Profile Tour of Asia Hits Speed Bumps
item.description: No trade agreement with Japan, and vitriol from China.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: President Obama being welcomed by Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko of Japan at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

item.title: Attack on Journalist Starts Battle in Pakistani Press
item.description: Accusations that the country’s spy agency was involved in the attack have led to a divisive debate and demands that a television station be shut down.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A vigil in Karachi on Thursday for the journalist Hamid Mir, who was wounded by gunmen. His station, Geo News, accused the intelligence agency of involvement.

item.title: Five Killed in Fierce Gun Battle in Kashmir
item.description: Three suspected rebels and two Indian Army soldiers were killed in a fierce gun battle in Indian-controlled Kashmir, officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Slow, Grinding Strategy of Inflicting Syria Misery
item.description: The government may have the upper hand, but its forces are worn down, heavily dependent on outside assistance and unable to reclaim large sections of the country from rebels.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Uncredited/Shaam News Network, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Children receiving oxygen in Kfar Zeita, a rebel-held village. Residents of rebel-held areas say they have been targeted with chlorine gas.

item.title: News Analysis: On a Trip That Avoids Beijing, Obama Keeps His Eye on China
item.description: Perhaps no country has more to gain from a new Cold War than China, which has historically benefited from periods of conflict between the United States and Russia, analysts say.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama at a state dinner in Malaysia, one of four stops on his Asia tour, with King Abdul Halim and Queen Haminah.

item.title: Obama Opens Long-Awaited Visit to Malaysia
item.description: In the first visit to the country by an American president in nearly half a century, President Obama landed in Kuala Lumpur on Saturday and planned economic and security talks with Prime Minister Najib Razak.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: President Obama inspected an honor guard on Saturday during a welcoming ceremony outside the Parliament house in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

item.title: Sainthood for 2 Predecessors Allows Pope to Straddle Divide
item.description: John XXIII, revered by Roman Catholic liberals, and John Paul II, beloved by conservatives, will be recognized as saints at a Mass on Sunday as Pope Francis pushes his own vision of a church under a big tent.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: The Roman Catholic church is canonizing John Paul II, left in a portrait in Vatican City on Saturday, and John XXIII.
